Muy buena expansi√≥n, no solo se siente como half life, si no que es un half life entre comillas mejorado.

Agrega mas armas y no son reskins de las originales en half life (a excepcion de la desert eagle aunque esta incluye una mira laser) tambien implementa nuevas mecanicas como escalar usando un barnacle de mano, subir cuerdas y el usar soldados con soplete para abrir puertas y medicos soldados para salvar otros soldados y poder usarlos. Mencionando tambien la vision nocturna en vez de la linterna.

Tambien introduce nuevos enemigos, tomando de ejemplo a la raza x que es una version alien de los propios marines y sin cortar ningun enemigo del half life , una expansion muy completa, recomendadis√≠ma.

Half life opposing force is how expansions are supposed to be . Short experiences that encapsulate everything the base game does well while expanding on it's formula and opposing force does just that . Half life's frantic firefights , great atmosphere , fantastic pacing , interesting set pieces and great weapons are all here and half life opposing force adds even more with a load of new weapons which are all unique and create new ways to also interact with the world . The new enemies are varied and all there encounters feel different . The last boss is tedious and a lot of the problems half life had are still here like the annoying platforming but this game expands and on what made half life so good and I wholly recommend it .

One of two expansion packs for the original Half-Life (the other being Blue Shift; we don't count Decay, as it's a PS2 "game" and the PC Illuminati have no time for the console ignorami [redundant, I know]) by Gearbox, Opposing Force is the better of the two.  My main reason for saying so is the presence of new weapons in the game, including a handful of alien weapons, several of which make the gameplay much more interesting.  

Otherwise, the game is very similar to Half-Life; you work your way through a messed up situation, both indoors and outdoors, fight aliens and humans, and try to survive.  Sure, you now work with Marines to bust down doors, but that's a pretty small thing.  Much like Blast Pit in the original, you kill a big monster by going to opposite ends of the level to activate switches.  

If you like the original, I can't see much of a reason not to play this one.  Good stuff.

Initially I wasn't very interested in the idea of playing the events of Half-Life through the eyes of the enemy, but I was in for quite the shock.

This is a very very good sequel/DLC/add-on thing to the original Half-Life. A lot of effort went into this and you can tell. I was surprised and delighted with all the new things they added into this game. From the new enemies, and weapons to the new mechanics as well; it was a good time the whole way through. In some ways, it may be better than the original, but that's mostly because I felt the original was a tad too long. I am a slow player though :/

Overall: 9/10

If all you want from Opposing Force is "more Black Mesa," it delivers that. What it doesn't deliver is any kind of coherence. There is no real campaign storyline, just a series of maps that are so disconnected that sometimes the game zaps you straight from one to another. In Half-Life you were the hero. In Opposing Force, you're an extra.

very goode and fun game

If you enjoyed Halflife 1, get this game. 

This expansion is full of new mechanics and what makes this great is that it tries to be different to Halflife 1. The guards are different, the guns are different, the flashlight is different, even the zombies look different. What truly differentiates it is its focus. This game has a story of course, but it's a progression is a lot more focused on harder combat, a lot more platforming and a lot more utilising of NPCs; it's less lever turning or sequence solving than what there was in Halflife 1. It's a different experience, but it still feels like Halflife 1 and is still fun to play, Corporal Shepherd is also a cool character and he has some pretty cool interactions Gordon Freeman never managed to have. The stories of Halflife 1 and Opposing Force aren't just completely isolated either, there's plenty of brilliant crossovers between both.

I will say, however, that while the ending was cool, the final sort of "hurdle" was kind of easy, even on a hard difficulty, but the rest of the game can be very hard, more so than the first as there is a lot less handholding as it expects the player to already to be accustomed to Halflife.

Awesome alternative view of Gordon Freemans spaghetti debacle.

Opposing force is the first of the alternate perspectives of the events of the original Half Life story. This chapter is centered on the military and their mission to kill Gordon Freeman. Just like Half Life, this is an amazing story that only serves to boost the quality of the story of the resonance cascade. If you enjoyed Half Life, this will be an excellent addition to the story and a fun game on its own.
